transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Hello, thank you for participating in this interview. I'm going to ask you some questions about your health and experiences. Let's begin.

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Hello, thank you for having me. I appreciate the opportunity to share my experiences. I'm ready when you are. 

**Interviewer:** Great, Ava. To start, could you tell me about your experiences with prenatal care during your pregnancies? What was your overall experience like?

**Ava:** Well, I had two pregnancies, both of which were pretty much the same in terms of prenatal care. I went to the clinic for check-ups, but it was mostly just the basics—checking the heartbeat and doing some blood tests. I felt like I didn’t get a lot of information or support beyond that. 

**Interviewer:** I see. Can you tell me more about the challenges you faced in accessing prenatal care? 

**Ava:** One of the biggest challenges was transportation. We live in a rural area, and getting to the clinic wasn’t always easy. Sometimes my husband had to take time off work to drive me, and if he couldn’t, I just had to miss appointments. It was frustrating because I wanted to make sure everything was okay with my pregnancies.

**Interviewer:** That sounds really tough. Did you have any support systems in place to help you with transportation or any other needs during your pregnancies?

**Ava:** Not really. I had some friends, but they were busy with their own families. I felt pretty isolated at times. I wish I had more support or even someone to talk to about what I was going through.

**Interviewer:** It sounds like you went through a lot alone. Did you ever have any difficulties accessing information about your health or prenatal care options?

**Ava:** Yes, definitely. I didn’t always know what questions to ask or what I should be doing. I tried looking things up online, but it was hard to find reliable information. I wish there had been someone to guide me through it all.

**Interviewer:** Thank you for sharing that, Ava. It’s important to have access to reliable information. How would you describe your overall health during your pregnancies? Did you experience any pregnancy-related conditions?

**Ava:** I had some common issues, like morning sickness and fatigue. I didn’t really have any serious complications, but I did feel a lot of stress because of everything going on. I think the lack of support and access to care added to that.

**Interviewer:** That sounds very challenging. Did you have any particular experiences or feelings that stand out from your pregnancies in terms of your mental health?

**Ava:** I definitely felt overwhelmed at times. The stress of taking care of two kids already, plus being pregnant, was a lot. I tried to stay positive, but I often felt anxious about how I was going to manage everything. 

**Interviewer:** It’s understandable to feel that way. It’s a big transition, especially with limited resources. Looking back, is there anything you wish you could have changed about your prenatal care experience?

**Ava:** I wish I had better access to healthcare and more informative prenatal classes. I think if I had someone to talk to regularly—like a nurse or a counselor—it would have made a big difference. Just having someone listen and guide me through it would have helped a lot.

**Interviewer:** Those are very valid points, Ava. Thank you for sharing your thoughts. As a follow-up, how do you feel about your current access to healthcare now that you've had your children? 

**Ava:** It’s still tough. I have Medicaid, but getting to appointments is still a challenge. I don’t go as often as I probably should because I worry about how to get there. It’s frustrating because I want to take care of myself too.

**Interviewer:** I can understand that. Taking care of your health is just as important. Lastly, how do you view the role of your community in supporting maternal health? Do you feel there are resources available for mothers like you?

**Ava:** I don’t see many resources around here. I think if there were more community programs focused on mothers, it could really help. It would be great to have more local support groups or health fairs where we could learn about our health and get connected with services.

**Interviewer:** Thank you so much for sharing your experiences, Ava. Your insights are incredibly valuable, and they highlight some important areas for improvement in maternal health support. Is there anything else you would like to add before we conclude the interview?

**Ava:** No, I think you’ve covered everything. I just hope my experience can help others in similar situations. Thank you for listening. 

**Interviewer:** Thank you for your openness and for sharing your journey with me today, Ava. Your voice is important, and I appreciate your time.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me a bit about yourself and your current life situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
**Ava:** Sure! Right now, I’m a stay-at-home mom, taking care of my two kids. They keep me busy! My oldest is five, and my youngest is two. It can be quite a handful, especially since they’re both so energetic. I love being home with them, but sometimes I feel like I miss having a job and that sense of independence. We live in a small town in Montana, and while it's beautiful out here, the isolation can be tough. I don't have family nearby, so I mostly rely on my husband for support. He works hard to provide for us, but sometimes it feels like I’m carrying a lot of the family responsibilities on my own. 

Since I have a high school diploma, I’ve thought about going back to school or looking for a part-time job, but with the kids being so young and the transportation issues, it just hasn’t been feasible right now. I really want to make sure I’m taking care of myself too, but sometimes it’s hard to find the time or resources to do that.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your pregnancy or pregnancies? When did you first learn you were pregnant?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
**Ava:** I found out I was pregnant with my first child when I was about six weeks along. I remember feeling a mix of excitement and nervousness. I took a home pregnancy test after I missed my period, and when it came back positive, I was thrilled but also overwhelmed. It was a big change, and I wasn’t sure what to expect.

For my second pregnancy, I found out when my first was just about a year old. I was a little more prepared the second time around, but I still had those same feelings of excitement mixed with anxiety, especially about how I would manage two little ones.

With both pregnancies, I really hoped to learn as much as I could about what to expect, but like I mentioned before, I didn’t feel like I had enough support or information. It was often just me figuring things out as I went along. 

**Interviewer:** That’s understandable, Ava. It sounds like both pregnancies came with their own set of challenges and feelings. How did you feel about the timing of your pregnancies? Did you feel prepared for both of them?

**Ava:** The first pregnancy was a surprise, but I think we were both excited. With the second one, I felt a little more prepared since I had gone through it once before, but I also worried about how I would manage everything with two kids so close in age. Sometimes, I felt like I wasn’t ready, especially since my first was still so young. It was a lot to take in! 

**Interviewer:** It sounds like there was a lot to balance with both pregnancies. Did you have any specific hopes or plans for how you wanted your pregnancies to go, or for after your babies were born?

**Ava:** I really wanted to have healthy pregnancies and deliveries, and I hoped to bond with my babies after they were born. I also wanted to be able to take care of myself and not lose sight of my own health and well-being. I think I hoped for more resources or support to help me through that, but it didn't quite happen the way I imagined. 

**Interviewer:** Thank you for sharing that, Ava. It’s really important to have those hopes and plans, and it’s understandable that things don’t always go as envisioned. How did you feel about your postpartum experience after each delivery? 

**Ava:** After my first, I was really tired and just trying to adjust to being a new mom. I had some baby blues, I think, but I didn’t really talk to anyone about it. After my second, it was a bit more chaotic, managing a toddler and a newborn. I felt even more overwhelmed and isolated, and I wished I had someone to talk to about what I was feeling. I tried my best to stay positive, but it was hard with so much going on. 

**Interviewer:** That sounds really challenging, Ava. It’s so important to have support during that time. Did you feel like you were able to connect with any resources or services for postpartum care?

**Ava:** Not really. I didn’t have much access to postpartum care or support groups in my area. I mostly just relied on my husband and tried to get by. I think some local resources could have made a big difference, but at the time, I just didn’t know where to look or what was available. 

**Interviewer:** Thank you for sharing your experiences with both your pregnancies and postpartum care. It’s clear that support is crucial during those times. Is there anything else you would like to share about your journey or your thoughts on maternal health?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: When did you first seek prenatal care? What was that experience like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
**Ava:** I first sought prenatal care when I found out I was pregnant with my first child, around six weeks. I went to the local clinic for my first appointment, and I remember being nervous but also excited to see the doctor. They did the usual tests and confirmed the pregnancy, but it felt pretty rushed. I had to fill out a lot of paperwork and then wait for the check-up. The doctor was nice, but I felt like I didn’t get to ask all the questions I had in my head. It was mostly just checking the heartbeat and a few other basics. 

For my second pregnancy, I tried to go in a little earlier, thinking I could get more information or support. But again, it was similar—just the basic check-ups. I wanted to talk more about my concerns and what I could do to stay healthy, but it was hard to get the time and attention I needed. 

**Interviewer:** It sounds like both experiences were somewhat similar. Did you feel comfortable discussing your needs or concerns with the healthcare providers during those visits?

**Ava:** Not really. I felt a little intimidated and like I didn’t want to take up too much of their time. Plus, sometimes I wasn’t even sure what to ask. I wished I could have had a little more one-on-one time to really dive into my questions, especially since I was feeling so many things—anxiety, excitement, and a bit of fear about being a mom again. 

**Interviewer:** That makes sense, Ava. It’s important to feel comfortable and supported during those visits. Were there any particular topics or concerns you wish you had been able to address more thoroughly with your provider?

**Ava:** I really wanted to talk about managing my stress and anxiety, especially with having two kids. I also wished I could have gotten more information on what to expect postpartum because I felt pretty unprepared for that side of things. I think if I had known more about the emotional and physical changes I would go through, it might have helped me feel more at ease. 

**Interviewer:** Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like having more comprehensive discussions about mental health and postpartum care would have been beneficial for you. Were there any specific resources or support services you wished you had access to during your prenatal care visits?

**Ava:** Yes, definitely. I think if there were classes or support groups for new moms, that would have been really helpful. Just having a space to connect with others and share experiences could have made a difference. I also wished there were pamphlets or information sessions about what to expect during and after pregnancy. It would have helped me feel more informed and less alone. 

**Interviewer:** Those are great suggestions, Ava. Thank you for sharing your thoughts on what could improve the prenatal care experience. Is there anything else you’d like to mention about your journey or your experiences with healthcare overall? 

**Ava:** I just hope that sharing my story can help others who might be feeling the same way. I think it’s really important for mothers, especially in rural areas, to have better access to support and information. It can be so isolating, and every mom deserves to feel heard and cared for. 

**Interviewer:** Thank you so much for your openness, Ava. Your experiences and insights are incredibly valuable, and they can contribute to meaningful changes in maternal healthcare. I appreciate your time today.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who is providing your prenatal care? Can you describe your relationship with your healthcare provider?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
**Ava:** My prenatal care was provided by a local clinic. The healthcare provider I saw was a general practitioner, not an obstetrician, which I think was part of the issue. I didn’t have a consistent doctor for my pregnancies; it was usually whoever was available when I went in. Sometimes it felt like I was just another patient in line, and I didn’t really build a relationship with any of them. 

I appreciated their care, but I often felt rushed during appointments. They were nice, but I didn’t feel like I could really connect or open up about my concerns. I think having a dedicated provider who knows my history and can take the time to listen would have made a big difference in my experience. I really wanted someone who understood me and my situation, especially since I was going through such a big life change. 

**Interviewer:** It sounds like consistency and connection were lacking in your prenatal care experience. How do you think having a more established relationship with a healthcare provider would have impacted your prenatal care?

**Ava:** I think it would have made me feel more comfortable sharing my worries and asking questions. When you’re pregnant, there’s so much to think about, and having someone who really knows you and your background could help tailor the conversations to what I really needed. I would have felt more supported and less alone in navigating my pregnancies. It’s tough when you feel like you’re just another number in the system. 

**Interviewer:** That’s a very valid point, Ava. Building trust and rapport with a healthcare provider can significantly enhance the care experience. Is there anything else you’d like to share about your experience with healthcare providers during your pregnancies? 

**Ava:** I just wish there could be more emphasis on building relationships in healthcare, especially for expectant mothers. It’s such a critical time, and having someone who’s genuinely invested in your well-being can make all the difference. I think it would help with mental health too, knowing you have someone in your corner who understands your journey. 

**Interviewer:** Thank you for sharing that perspective, Ava. It’s so important to foster those relationships in healthcare. Your experiences and thoughts can truly help inform improvements in maternal care. Is there anything else you would like to discuss about your healthcare experiences or any other topics related to maternal health?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How often do you have prenatal appointments? Can you walk me through what a typical visit is like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
**Ava:** During my pregnancies, I had appointments about once a month in the beginning, and then they increased to every two weeks as I got closer to my due date. A typical visit for me usually started with checking in at the front desk and filling out some paperwork if needed. Then, I’d wait for a little while until a nurse would call me back.

Once in the exam room, they would take my weight, check my blood pressure, and listen to the baby’s heartbeat, which was always a relief to hear. After that, I’d meet with the doctor or nurse practitioner for a quick chat. They would ask if I had any questions or concerns, but honestly, it felt like the appointments were pretty brief—maybe 10 to 15 minutes at most. 

They’d do some basic tests, like checking my urine, and then I’d be on my way. I often left feeling like I still had more questions than answers. I really wanted to talk about things like my mental health, managing stress, and what to expect after the baby was born, but I just didn’t have the time or space to dive into those topics. 

**Interviewer:** It sounds like your appointments were quite brief and focused on the basics. Did you feel like you had enough time to address your concerns, or did you feel rushed during those visits?

**Ava:** I definitely felt rushed. I’d often think of questions on the way to the appointment or even while I was waiting, but by the time I got in there, I felt so pressured to just get through the basics that I didn’t want to hold them up. I think if I had a little more time to discuss my concerns, it would have helped me feel more prepared and supported. 

**Interviewer:** That’s understandable, Ava. Feeling rushed can really impact your ability to communicate effectively with your provider. Were there any specific questions or topics that you wish you had been able to discuss more in-depth during your appointments?

**Ava:** Yes, I really wanted to talk about what to expect postpartum, especially the emotional side of things. I also had concerns about managing two kids and how to take care of myself in the process. I wished I could have gotten advice on coping strategies or even just reassurance that what I was feeling was normal. 

**Interviewer:** Those are important topics that deserve attention during prenatal care. Thank you for sharing your experiences with your appointments. Is there anything else about your prenatal visits or overall healthcare experience that you would like to share?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you experienced any health concerns or complications during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
**Ava:** Thankfully, I didn’t have any major complications during my pregnancies. I had the usual morning sickness and some fatigue, but nothing serious. However, I did experience a lot of stress, especially with managing my home life and the challenges of being a new mom with a toddler while pregnant. 

There were moments when I worried about my mental health, especially after my second child was born. I didn’t necessarily have postpartum depression, but I did feel overwhelmed, anxious, and a bit lost. I think if I had more support or resources to help understand what I was going through, it might have helped me cope better. 

I also had some concerns about my weight during my pregnancies. I felt like I was gaining more than I should have, and while my doctors didn’t express any major concerns, I sometimes felt insecure about it. I wish we could have talked more about healthy habits and managing weight from a mental and physical health perspective. 

**Interviewer:** It sounds like you navigated some significant stressors during your pregnancies, even without major medical complications. Did you find any strategies that helped you manage that stress or your overall well-being during that time?

**Ava:** I tried to focus on taking care of myself when I could, like going for short walks or finding time to relax when the kids were napping. But honestly, it was hard to prioritize myself with everything going on. I didn’t have a lot of time to dedicate to self-care, and sometimes it felt like there was just no break. I really wish I had access to resources that could have helped me learn more about managing stress and mental health during this time. 

**Interviewer:** It’s understandable that finding that balance is challenging, especially with young children. Thank you for sharing those insights, Ava. Your experiences highlight the need for more comprehensive support when it comes to maternal health and mental well-being. Is there anything else you would like to add regarding your health concerns during your pregnancies?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What medications or supplements are you currently taking?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
**Ava:** Right now, I'm not taking any medications or supplements. During my pregnancies, I was prescribed prenatal vitamins, which I took regularly, but since having my kids, I haven't really focused on taking any supplements. I know I should probably be more proactive about my health, but with everything going on, it's been hard to remember to take anything. I try to eat a balanced diet, but some days it's just whatever I can manage with the kids. I’ve thought about talking to my doctor about what I should be taking now that I’m not pregnant, but again, it's just finding the time to get to an appointment. 

**Interviewer:** That makes sense, Ava. It’s important to prioritize your health, especially after having children. Have you considered any specific vitamins or supplements that you think might be beneficial for you at this point in your life?

**Ava:** I’ve heard about things like vitamin D and omega-3s being helpful, but I’m not sure what would be best for me. I think I could use some guidance on that. I want to make sure I’m taking care of myself, not just for me but also for my kids. It’s just hard to know where to start without feeling overwhelmed.

**Interviewer:** It's completely understandable to feel that way. Getting the right information and support can make a big difference. Thank you for sharing your experiences with medications and supplements. Is there anything else on this topic or any other aspect of your health that you would like to discuss?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your diet and nutrition during pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
**Ava:** During my pregnancies, I tried to focus on eating healthy, but it was definitely a challenge. I aimed to include more fruits and vegetables, and I made sure to have protein in my meals. However, with morning sickness, I often found myself craving things like crackers and toast, which weren’t the healthiest options. 

There were days when I felt like I was doing well with my diet, but then there were other days when I just didn’t have the energy to cook or prepare meals. Sometimes it was just easier to grab something quick, especially with a toddler running around. I really wished I could have had more guidance on what to eat to support my health and the babies' health during pregnancy. 

After my pregnancies, I’ve tried to maintain a balanced diet, but again, it’s hard to find the time, and I often end up eating what’s quick and easy. I know I should be more mindful about my nutrition, especially since I want to set a good example for my kids. 

**Interviewer:** It sounds like you put in a lot of effort to focus on your nutrition, even when it was difficult. Did you find any specific resources or support that helped you with meal planning or nutrition during your pregnancies?

**Ava:** Not really. I tried looking up recipes online and reading about healthy eating during pregnancy, but it was overwhelming sometimes. I think if there had been more local resources or classes on nutrition for pregnant women, it would have helped a lot. Just having someone to talk to about meal ideas or planning would have made it easier to stay on track. 

**Interviewer:** That’s a great point, Ava. Access to nutrition resources can really empower expectant mothers to make healthier choices. Thank you for sharing your experiences with your diet during pregnancy. Is there anything else you’d like to add regarding your nutrition or any challenges you faced?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How have you been feeling emotionally during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
**Ava:** Emotionally, my pregnancies were a mixed bag. At first, I felt a lot of excitement and joy about becoming a mom, but as time went on, I also experienced a lot of anxiety and stress. With my first pregnancy, I was mostly just trying to figure everything out, and I remember feeling overwhelmed by the changes happening in my body and my life.

After my second child was born, I felt even more pressure. Managing a toddler and a newborn was exhausting, and there were days when I felt like I was barely keeping it together. I often felt anxious about how I was going to manage everything, and I wished I had someone to talk to who understood what I was going through. 

I didn’t really talk about my feelings much, partly because I didn’t want to burden anyone and also because I wasn’t sure if what I was feeling was normal. I did have some moments of sadness and feeling lost, especially after my second baby was born. I think if I had had more support or resources to help me understand and process those emotions, it would have made a big difference. 

**Interviewer:** It sounds like you experienced quite a range of emotions during your pregnancies, which is completely understandable given the circumstances. Did you have any coping strategies that helped you manage those feelings, or did you find it difficult to find ways to cope?

**Ava:** I tried to focus on the good moments, like feeling the baby kick or seeing the ultrasound pictures, but honestly, it was hard to find time for myself. I didn’t have a lot of time to relax or unwind. Sometimes I would just take a few minutes to breathe and remind myself that I was doing my best. But it felt like I needed more support, like someone to check in on me and help me process everything. 

**Interviewer:** Thank you for sharing that, Ava. It’s important to recognize the emotional side of pregnancy and motherhood. Is there anything else you’d like to share about your emotional experiences during your pregnancies or any support you wish you had?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who supports you during your pregnancy? Can you tell me about your support network?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
**Ava:** My main source of support during my pregnancies was my husband. He did his best to help me with the kids and was there for me when I needed someone to talk to. However, sometimes he was also busy with work and other responsibilities, so I felt like I was carrying a lot of the emotional load on my own.

I have a few friends, but most of them were also busy with their own families, so it was hard to connect with them about what I was going through. I felt pretty isolated at times, especially in our rural area where there aren’t many local resources or community groups for expecting mothers. I wish I had more access to a support network, like a group for moms where we could share experiences and advice. 

Overall, I think the lack of a broader support system made things feel more overwhelming. I really wanted someone to understand what I was going through, and it would have been nice to have a community of other moms to lean on. 

**Interviewer:** It's understandable to feel isolated, especially during such a significant life change. Having a supportive network can make a big difference. Are there any specific types of support or resources that you wish you had access to during your pregnancies? 

**Ava:** Yes, I think having access to a local support group for expecting moms would have been really helpful. Just having a place to share experiences, ask questions, and connect with others in similar situations would have made me feel less alone. Also, resources like parenting classes or workshops on managing stress and mental health during pregnancy would have been beneficial. I think that would’ve helped a lot of moms in our area feel more supported and connected. 

**Interviewer:** Those are valuable suggestions, Ava. Creating a strong support network and providing resources for mothers can certainly enhance their experiences. Thank you for sharing your thoughts on your support network during your pregnancies. Is there anything else about your support system or maternal health that you’d like to discuss?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about your birth plan? What are your preferences for delivery?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
**Ava:** I did think about my birth plan, but honestly, it was pretty simple. I wanted to have a vaginal delivery for both of my pregnancies, which I was able to do. My preference was to have as natural a birth as possible, but I also knew that I had to be flexible. 

With my first child, I was nervous and didn’t really know what to expect. I remember wanting to avoid unnecessary interventions, but when it came down to it, I just wanted to make sure my baby was healthy. I think I was so focused on the delivery itself that I didn’t really spend much time thinking about the whole experience or how I would handle pain management.

By the time I was pregnant with my second, I felt a little more prepared and confident, but the reality was that I still had a lot of anxiety about managing two little ones. I didn’t have a specific birth plan written down or anything like that. I just hoped for a safe delivery and to be able to hold my baby afterward.

I guess I wish I had thought more about my preferences for postpartum care as well, like how I wanted to be supported after the baby was born. It’s just so much to think about, and sometimes it felt overwhelming to plan for everything. 

**Interviewer:** It sounds like you had a focus on safety and health during your deliveries, which is completely understandable. Did you have any particular concerns or hopes regarding the birth experience itself, like who would be there with you or the environment you would be in?

**Ava:** I definitely wanted my husband there with me; he was my main support. I remember feeling nervous about being in the hospital and not knowing what to expect. I think having familiar faces around would have helped ease my anxiety. I also wished I could have had a more comfortable environment, but since we live in a rural area, I didn’t have many options for birthing centers or anything more home-like. 

I think if I had known more about what to expect and had a little more support in terms of my preferences for the environment, it would have made me feel more in control during the process. 

**Interviewer:** Those are important considerations, Ava. It’s clear that having support and comfort during delivery can impact the experience significantly. Is there anything else you’d like to share about your thoughts on your birth plan or preferences for delivery?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What sources of information have you used to learn about pregnancy and childbirth?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
**Ava:** I mostly relied on a mix of online resources and some books I found at the library. I tried to read up on pregnancy and childbirth as much as I could, especially since I didn’t have a lot of access to in-person classes or support groups. I looked for articles and forums online, but sometimes it was overwhelming because there’s so much information out there, and it can be hard to know what’s reliable.

I also watched some videos on YouTube about childbirth and parenting, which were helpful to see what others experienced, but I still felt like I needed more personalized guidance. I wish I could have attended local classes or workshops where I could learn from professionals and ask questions directly.

Overall, I think having more structured resources or community programs to guide me would have made a difference in how prepared I felt for both pregnancy and childbirth. 

**Interviewer:** It sounds like you utilized a variety of sources, but you still felt there was a gap in personalized support and information. Were there specific topics you were particularly interested in learning more about?

**Ava:** Yes, I really wanted to learn more about managing stress and anxiety during pregnancy, as well as what to expect postpartum. I also wished I had more information about newborn care, especially since I was going to have two young kids close in age. I think having access to local resources or classes that covered those topics would have helped me feel more confident and prepared. 

**Interviewer:** Those are very important topics, and it’s great that you were proactive in seeking out information. Thank you for sharing your experience with finding resources during your pregnancies. Is there anything else you’d like to share about the sources of information you used or any other aspects related to your pregnancy and childbirth education?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How are you managing the financial aspects of pregnancy and preparing for a baby?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
**Ava:** Managing the financial aspects of pregnancy has been challenging for us. Since we live on a limited income and my husband is the main breadwinner, we have to be very mindful of our expenses. We rely on Medicaid for our healthcare coverage, which helps with prenatal visits and delivery costs, but there are still out-of-pocket expenses that pop up, like co-pays for appointments or medications.

I’ve tried to budget as best as I can, but with the added costs of preparing for a new baby—like diapers, clothes, and other essentials—it can feel overwhelming. We often make do with hand-me-downs or second-hand items to save money. 

I also wish I had better access to resources that could help with budgeting or financial planning for families. It feels like there should be more community support for new parents, especially when it comes to managing the costs associated with having a baby. I think if there were workshops or classes focused on financial literacy for expecting parents, it could really help families like mine.

**Interviewer:** It sounds like you’re doing your best to navigate the financial side of things, even with the challenges you face. Have you found any specific resources or support that have helped you manage these costs?

**Ava:** Not really. I’ve looked around for local resources, but I haven’t found much. I’ve tried talking to friends and family for advice, but they’re also juggling their own expenses. I think if there were more community programs that focused on helping families prepare financially for a baby, it would make a big difference. Just having that support would help ease some of the stress around finances.

**Interviewer:** Thank you for sharing your experiences, Ava. It’s clear that financial support and resources are crucial for expecting families. Is there anything else you’d like to discuss regarding the financial aspects of pregnancy or preparing for a baby?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How has your pregnancy affected your work or employment situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
**Ava:** Since I'm a stay-at-home mom, my pregnancies didn't directly affect a job, but they did impact how I think about work and employment. I had to put any thoughts of returning to work on hold while I was pregnant and after having my children. It’s been a big adjustment, especially since I used to think about going back to school or finding a part-time job to contribute financially.

With my first pregnancy, I was still figuring out how to manage my time and responsibilities at home. By the time I got pregnant with my second, I realized that juggling two little ones would make it even more challenging to consider employment outside the home. I often feel like I miss having my own income, but I also know that being home with the kids is important for their development.

Sometimes I worry about what the future holds in terms of work. I know I need to think about my own career and independence, but right now, it just feels like I have to focus on raising the kids. I wish I had better access to resources or programs that could help me transition back into work when I’m ready. 

**Interviewer:** It sounds like you’ve had to make significant adjustments to your plans regarding work and employment. Do you have any specific goals or aspirations regarding your career for the future, once you feel ready to return to work?

**Ava:** Yes, I’ve thought about going back to school to get a degree or certification in something I’m passionate about—maybe in early childhood education or healthcare. I think it would be fulfilling to work in a field where I can help others, especially since I have my own experience as a mom. But it all depends on finding the time and resources to make that happen, which feels daunting right now. 

**Interviewer:** Those are admirable goals, Ava. Having a clear direction for your future can be motivating. Thank you for sharing your experiences regarding work and your thoughts on employment. Is there anything else you’d like to discuss about your work situation or any other related topics?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about the postpartum period? What plans do you have for after the baby arrives?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
**Ava:** Yes, I’ve thought about the postpartum period quite a bit, especially since I felt a bit overwhelmed after my second child was born. I want to make sure I take care of myself this time around. My main plan is to lean on my husband for support as much as possible, as he’s been great about helping out with the kids. 

I also want to try to prioritize self-care, even if it’s just taking a few moments for myself when I can. I know how important it is to process my emotions and not just push through everything. I’ve considered reaching out to some local resources for postpartum support, like mothers’ groups or counseling, but I haven’t found anything concrete yet. 

Honestly, I’m a little anxious about how I’ll manage with two kids and a newborn, but I’m hoping to set realistic expectations for myself. I want to be gentle with myself and allow time to adjust to the new routine. I also think I’d like to have conversations with my healthcare provider about what signs to look for regarding postpartum depression or anxiety, so I can be more aware and proactive about my mental health.

**Interviewer:** It’s great to hear that you’re thinking ahead and planning for your postpartum experience. It sounds like you’re aware of the importance of support and self-care during that time. Are there any specific areas where you feel you might need additional support or resources after the baby arrives?

**Ava:** I think having access to information about postpartum health and recovery would be really helpful. I’d like to know more about what to expect physically and emotionally during that time. Also, just having a support network in place would make me feel more secure. If there were local groups for new moms or resources that offered advice on handling the transition, that would be invaluable. I really want to feel connected and not isolated like I did before.

**Interviewer:** Those are very valid points. Having the right information and support can make a significant difference in the postpartum experience. Thank you for sharing your thoughts and plans for after the baby arrives. Is there anything else on this topic or any other aspects of your journey that you’d like to discuss?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Thank you for your time and for sharing your experiences with me. This concludes our interview.
